nameString.en: How is a raven like a chair?

task.en: You‚Äôll get two random things. Think about what they might have in common, and try to find an unexpected connection between them.

example.en: A raven is like a chair because both can stand on one leg and still look confident üòÑ

description.en:
üåÄ In this exercise, you connect things that seem to have nothing in common ‚Äî like a raven and a chair. Your task: come up with a creative, funny, or just logical reason why these two are alike.

üéØ Trains: divergent thinking | improvisation | sense of humor

Your answer can be absurd or brilliant ‚Äî what matters is that it‚Äôs yours!

task.en: Say the tongue twisters out loud ‚Äî clearly, rhythmically, and without stumbling. Pronounce each one in three stages: first slowly, then faster, and finally very fast, several times in a row

example.en: Example: She sells seashells by the seashore.

description.en:
üëÖ Easy tongue twisters are a great way to warm up your articulation and get your voice ready for bigger challenges. Say each one clearly and expressively in three stages: first slowly, then faster, and finally as fast as you can ‚Äî without stumbling.

üéØ Trains: articulation | pronunciation clarity | verbal coordination

Don‚Äôt let the simplicity fool you ‚Äî once you speed up, your tongue might twist!

task.en: Your task is to come up with a witty, funny excuse to amuse your conversation partner and show creativity.

example.en:
Accusation: You stole the moon!
Excuse: ‚ÄúI just wanted to light the way, and the moon winked at me!‚Äù

description.en:
üé≠ In this exercise, you become a master of quick excuses. You get a playful accusation ‚Äî and your mission is to come up with a witty explanation that makes people smile or raises an eyebrow. All it takes is a bit of creativity and humor!

üß† Trains: creativity | humor | quick thinking

Spin your excuse, keep it clever ‚Äî and leave them laughing!

nameString.en: Talk Until You Run Out of Air

task.en: You‚Äôll get a random word ‚Äî and you start talking. Describe the object from every possible angle: what it looks like, where you might find it, how it's used, what's funny or unique about it, and what memories or associations it evokes. Talk for at least 2 minutes nonstop.

example.en:
Word: toaster.

Well, a toaster is a household appliance that helps you have breakfast quickly and deliciously. As a kid, I thought it was magical because bread would jump out by itself. Usually, it has two slots, but there are four-slot models too. Some toasters have a defrost button‚ÄîI still don‚Äôt know what it‚Äôs for. There‚Äôs a legend that if something gets stuck, never poke it with a fork‚Äîbecause that‚Äôs dangerous...

description.en:
üó£Ô∏è In this exercise, you‚Äôll be given a random object and talk about it nonstop for at least 2 minutes. Describe its appearance, purpose, curious features or associations.

üéØ Trains: speech endurance | creativity | spontaneous speaking

task.en: You‚Äôll get a part of speech (e.g., nouns, verbs, or adjectives). Your task is to name as many words of that type as you can. The more you say ‚Äî the better your score.

example.en:
Part of speech: Verbs
Answer: run, read, think, write, shout, sleep‚Ä¶

description.en:
‚ö°Ô∏è You‚Äôll get a category of words ‚Äî for example, verbs or adjectives. Your task is to name as many words from this category as possible, one after another, quickly and without pauses.

Time is limited, so speed and fluency matter.

üéØ Trains: vocabulary | verbal reaction

task.en: You‚Äôll see words on the screen. Your task is to say their antonyms

example.en:
Word: ‚Äúwarm‚Äù ‚Üí Answer: ‚Äúcold‚Äù
Word: ‚Äútall‚Äù ‚Üí Answer: ‚Äúshort‚Äù

description.en:
‚öîÔ∏è In this exercise, you're in a word duel: you get a word ‚Äî and must instantly say its antonym. For example, ‚Äúlight‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúdark‚Äù, ‚Äústrong‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúweak‚Äù. The task: think fast, sharp, and right.

üéØ Trains: vocabulary | associative thinking | language reflexes

task.en: Create a story using all four given words.

example.en:
Words: lantern, cat, boat, song.

Story: Once, a cat found an old boat, climbed in, and floated down the river, lighting the way with a lantern. And whenever the waves grew stronger, he would hum his favorite song‚Äîand the waters would calm down.

description.en:
üìö In this exercise, you create a story using four random words. They may come from different areas and seem unrelated.

üéØ Trains: imagination | narrative flow | mental flexibility

Even the strangest words can form a captivating story ‚Äî just let your imagination run free!

task.en: You get a word and imagine you're a seller. Your goal is to convince a unique customer that this item will change their life. Use vivid descriptions, benefits, emotion, humor or drama ‚Äî whatever helps make the item desirable. Even if it‚Äôs just a paperclip.

example.en:
Word: regular spoon.

Friends, this spoon is not just cutlery. It‚Äôs your ticket to convenience, style, and unmatched reliability. Curved to perfection so every bite of soup is a delight. Made from a material that could survive an apocalypse. Buy this spoon today ‚Äî and no porridge will ever be boring again!

description.en:
üß≤ In this exercise, you become a master of persuasion and make anything sound desirable. Your task is to sell the item using words: descriptions, benefits, emotions or even clever manipulation.

üéØ Trains: creativity | persuasive delivery | improvisation

The more ordinary the item ‚Äî the more fun it is to sell it!

task.en: You‚Äôll get a word ‚Äî and you must write a definition so clear and precise that it can‚Äôt be confused with anything else. Avoid vague language. Clarify: what it‚Äôs for, what it‚Äôs made of, how it looks, and how it differs from similar things.

example.en:
Word: thermometer.

Definition: A device designed to measure the temperature of a body, liquid, or air. It consists of a sealed tube with a liquid or an electronic sensor. Unlike a barometer, it does not measure pressure ‚Äî only temperature, usually in Celsius or Fahrenheit.

description.en:
üîç In this exercise, your job is to describe the given item clearly and in detail. Your description should leave no doubt about what it is.

üéØ Trains: attention to detail | language precision | vocabulary

task.en: Your task is to come up with as many meanings or associations of this word as possible.

example.en:
Word: Key
Meanings: a tool for a lock, a water spring, a solution to a problem, a musical symbol, a way to access something.

description.en:
üîë In this exercise, you‚Äôll dive into the many meanings of everyday words. One word ‚Äî and so many possibilities! Think of what it can represent, recall associations, or invent new ones.

üéØ Trains: linguistic flexibility | creativity | vocabulary

Look at familiar words from a fresh angle ‚Äî and discover whole new worlds!

nameString.en: Big Answer to a Small Question

task.en: You‚Äôll get a simple question ‚Äî and your job is to answer it in a detailed, vivid, and creative way

example.en:
Question: What's your favorite tea?
Answer: My favorite tea is jasmine. Because it smells like spring in a library ‚Äî where intellect meets floral vibes. It‚Äôs the tea for moments when you want a bit of silence, a bit of aesthetics, and a bit of yourself.

description.en:
üéô In this exercise, you‚Äôll be given a simple question and your task is to answer it in a detailed, creative, and engaging way. Use imagination, humor, unexpected details, or exaggeration.

üéØ Trains: out-of-the-box thinking | creative speech | improvisation

task.en: Say the tongue twisters out loud ‚Äî fast, clearly, and without mistakes

example.en: Example: How much wood would a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood?

description.en:
üëÖ Time to level up ‚Äî medium tongue twisters demand more focus and verbal precision. Say each one aloud in three stages: slowly, faster, and then as fast as you can ‚Äî without slipping.

üéØ Trains: articulation | speech accuracy | rhythmic flow

task.en: You‚Äôll get a sentence where key words are dull or repetitive. Your task is to rephrase it using better, more precise or vivid synonyms, while keeping the meaning and tone

example.en:
Sentence: She was very nice and always said kind things.
Answer: She was sincere and constantly shared warm, encouraging thoughts.

description.en:
üß† In this exercise, you refine a sentence by replacing dull or repetitive words with sharper, more vivid, or simply better synonyms. Your task: keep the meaning, but say it more effectively.

üéØ Trains: vocabulary | language sensitivity | verbal precision

task.en: Get a controversial statement. First, come up with convincing arguments to support it ‚Äî even if you don‚Äôt agree. Then switch sides and try to refute it. The focus is on the strength of your reasoning, not your personal opinion.

example.en:
Statement: "School is unnecessary"
‚úÖ For: There are many successful people who never finished school. Self-education through the internet offers the freedom to learn what truly interests you.
‚ùå Against: School provides not just knowledge, but socialization, discipline, and teamwork skills. Without it, it‚Äôs hard to integrate into society.

description.en:
‚öñÔ∏è In this exercise, you receive a controversial statement. First, defend it with strong arguments ‚Äî even if you don‚Äôt agree. Then switch sides and try to refute it. What matters is not your opinion, but the strength of your reasoning.

üéØ Trains: mental flexibility | logic | ability to see multiple perspectives

task.en: Try to say a long sentence in one breath. Speak clearly, calmly, and don‚Äôt stop until the last word.

example.en: Sentence: ‚ÄúWhen the sun sets over the river, every shadow grows longer, and every sound becomes louder.‚Äù

description.en:
üí® This exercise helps you train your breath, diction, and vocal endurance. Your task: say a long sentence in one breath ‚Äî clearly, confidently, and all the way through.

üéØ Trains: breath control | diction | vocal stamina

task.en: You‚Äôll get a strange or everyday situation ‚Äî as if you‚Äôre an actor in a scene. Come up with a short monologue or some lines that could fit. Improvise, show emotion, and adapt to the moment.

example.en:
Situation: You‚Äôre stuck in an elevator with an alien.
Line: "Okay‚Ä¶ you don‚Äôt understand me, and I don‚Äôt get you. But if you eat my lunch ‚Äî it‚Äôs intergalactic war, got it?"

description.en:
üé≠ In this exercise, you‚Äôre placed in an imaginary scene ‚Äî strange, funny, or tense. Your task: come up with what you might say in that moment. A monologue, emotional reaction, or unexpected line ‚Äî anything works.

üéØ Trains: improvisation | emotional expression | creativity

Let yourself act, react, and go a little absurd ‚Äî this is the place for it!

task.en: You‚Äôll get an emotionally charged phrase. Try saying it calmly and neutrally ‚Äî without exaggeration, generalization, or blame. Express your thoughts in a way that avoids conflict.

example.en:
Phrase: "Everyone is driving me crazy!"
Factually: "I feel exhausted from having to interact with many people lately."

description.en:
üîÑ In this exercise, you turn emotional statements into factual, calm ones. Your task: lower the emotional charge and speak clearly ‚Äî without blame or aggression.

üéØ Trains: emotional intelligence | self-reflection

task.en: Get a random role ‚Äî like 'jealous pirate' or 'tired robot'. Imagine being this character and say a short monologue from their point of view. How do they think, feel, speak?

example.en:
Role: Tired robot
Monologue: ‚ÄúOne more task... One more file... I was built for efficiency, but today even joint oil doesn‚Äôt help. Humans, give me sleep mode...‚Äù

description.en:
üïµÔ∏è In this exercise, you become a fictional character ‚Äî and speak in their voice. Your task: deliver a monologue that expresses their personality, tone, and inner world.

üéØ Trains: expressiveness | flexible thinking

It‚Äôs your stage ‚Äî improvise and become anyone you like.

task.en: Say the hard tongue twisters out loud ‚Äî as fast and clearly as you can, without stumbling. Don‚Äôt stop, even if your tongue gets twisted!

example.en: Example: The sixth sick sheikh‚Äôs sixth sheep‚Äôs sick.

description.en:
üëÖ Ready for a real speech workout? Hard tongue twisters will push your diction to its limits. Say each one aloud in three rounds: first slowly, then faster, and finally at full speed ‚Äî without stopping, even if your tongue tangles.

üéØ Trains: verbal control | articulatory stamina | clear speech under pressure

Sounds tough? Perfect ‚Äî that‚Äôs the level where real mastery begins.

task.en: Get a random topic ‚Äî sometimes absurd, sometimes just weird. Deliver a short speech as if you‚Äôre a seasoned expert. Speak with confidence and persuasion, even if you‚Äôre making it all up.

example.en:
Topic: How to teach a turtle to play chess
Speech: ‚ÄúFirst, the turtle must realize pawns aren't food. After that, it's simple: one game a day, lots of praise, and within a month she‚Äôll beat any hedgehog!‚Äù

description.en:
ü•á In this exercise, you activate your inner TED speaker and talk with full confidence ‚Äî even if the topic sounds ridiculous. Your task: deliver a charismatic, fluent talk about something you know nothing about.

üéØ Trains: public speaking confidence | improvisation | persuasive delivery | charisma

task.en: You'll get a topic and a list of words you cannot use. Your task is to describe the topic or speak about it while avoiding the forbidden words

example.en:
Topic: Love
Forbidden words: heart, love, emotions
Answer: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the state when you wake up thinking of someone and the world feels slightly brighter just because they exist.‚Äù

description.en:
ü§ê Imagine trying to talk about love, but you're not allowed to say ‚Äúheart,‚Äù ‚Äúlove,‚Äù or ‚Äúemotions.‚Äù Sounds tricky? Give it a shot!

In this exercise, you‚Äôll get a topic and a list of forbidden words. Your task: express your thoughts on the topic without using any of the banned words. You‚Äôll need to find other paths, fresh phrasing, and creative descriptions.

üéØ Trains: creativity | verbal precision | linguistic flexibility

task.en: You‚Äôll receive an emotion or social situation. Your task is to show how it‚Äôs expressed through body language ‚Äî posture, facial expression, or gestures. You can perform it in front of a camera, a mirror, or describe it verbally.

example.en:
Situation: üëã You saw a friend from afar
Answer: I raise my hand above shoulder level, smile broadly, and lean slightly forward to show openness and joy.

description.en:
üßç‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Imagine you spot a friend from afar. No words ‚Äî just a wave, a smile, a posture. What does your body say?

In this exercise, you‚Äôll get an emotion or social situation. Your task: express it using only body language ‚Äî facial expressions, gestures, or posture. Perform it in front of a mirror, a camera, or describe it in words.

üéØ Trains: emotional expression | nonverbal communication | body awareness

Words aren‚Äôt the only way to speak. Let your body do the talking!

task.en: You‚Äôll get 3‚Äì5 random words. Your task is to create a rap verse using these words

example.en:
Words: window, cat, night, silence
Answer: ‚ÄúBy the window it‚Äôs quiet, my cat in sight ‚Äî
He listens to night while I spit rhymes tight.‚Äù

description.en:
üéß Imagine you get the words ‚Äúcat,‚Äù ‚Äúwindow,‚Äù and ‚Äúsilence‚Äù ‚Äî and within a minute, you're spitting a rhythmic verse that hits. Perfect rhyme? Optional. What matters is your delivery, rhythm, and creativity.

In this exercise, you‚Äôll receive 3‚Äì5 random words. Your task: build a rap verse using all of them. Don‚Äôt hold back ‚Äî play with sound, find your flow, and make it loud.

üéØ Trains: improvisation | verbal creativity | rhythmic thinking

task.en: You‚Äôll get a simple phrase (e.g., ‚ÄúI need tea!‚Äù) and a social context. Your task is to deliver the phrase as if you were in that situation ‚Äî as an actor, a diplomat, a teenager, a protester, etc. Focus on adapting tone, pace, and expression to the role.

example.en:
Phrase: ‚ÄúI need tea!‚Äù
Context: theater actor
Answer: (dramatically) ‚ÄúI... NEED... TEA!‚Äù

description.en:
üé≠ Imagine the simple phrase ‚ÄúI need tea!‚Äù ‚Äî but now you‚Äôre a diplomat in tense negotiations‚Ä¶ or a teenager begging their parent. How would you say it to make it convincing?

In this exercise, you‚Äôll receive a basic phrase and a social context. Your task: deliver the line as if you were in that role ‚Äî an actor, a politician, a protester, or someone else. Vary your tone, pace, volume, and emotion to match the scenario.

üéØ Trains: vocal expression | tonal flexibility | performance thinking

task.en: Your task is to convince an imaginary conversation partner to do something for you (e.g., lend you their umbrella) without using direct requests or commands. You must only hint, speak gently, and imply. No 'give me', 'do it', or even 'please do it'.

example.en:
Situation: You're soaking wet in the rain, and the other person is holding an umbrella.
Answer: ‚ÄúSeems like I misjudged the weather today‚Ä¶ Someone was clearly wiser than me to bring an umbrella.‚Äù

description.en:
üòè In this exercise, you practice getting what you want without saying it outright ‚Äî only through hints, emotional cues, and subtle delivery. Your task: persuade your imaginary partner to do something without using words like 'give' or 'do'.

üéØ Trains: indirect communication | emotional intelligence | linguistic flexibility

task.en: You‚Äôll get a sentence along with an instruction for how to say it ‚Äî for example, angrily, lovingly, or formally. Your task: say the sentence without changing the words, but clearly expressing the given emotion through your tone.

example.en:
Sentence: ‚ÄúI remember you well.‚Äù
Intonation styles:
1) Threat ‚Äî cold and tense.
2) Confession ‚Äî warm and soft.
3) Mockery ‚Äî with a sneer.
4) Formal speech ‚Äî clear and ceremonial.

description.en:
üé≠ In this exercise, you work with your voice and emotion. You‚Äôll get a sentence and a specific intonation to perform it with ‚Äî like a formal greeting, a harsh reproach, or a heartfelt confession.

üéØ Trains: intonation | emotional expression | diction

task.en: You see a word ‚Äî come up with a rhyme for it. It can be common or totally unexpected. The key is that it rhymes and sounds good!

example.en:
Word: ‚Äúsun‚Äù ‚Üí Answer: ‚Äúfun‚Äù, ‚Äúrun‚Äù
Word: ‚Äúday‚Äù ‚Üí Answer: ‚Äúplay‚Äù, ‚Äústay‚Äù

description.en:
‚ö° In this exercise, you train your rapid-fire rhyme instinct. You see a word ‚Äî and need to come up with a rhyme: familiar, quirky, or unexpected. The key is that it sounds good!

üéØ Trains: rhyming | linguistic agility | creativity

Play with words like music ‚Äî let your rhymes hit fast and shine bright!

task.en: You will get a question ‚Äî come up with the funniest, most original answer.

example.en:
Question: Why were you late for the date?
Answer: ‚ÄúTraffic on Mars was terrible, so I had to choose between red lights and black holes.‚Äù

description.en:
üòÇ In this exercise, your weapon is wit. You‚Äôll get a question and must answer it in a way that makes people laugh or at least raise an eyebrow. The more absurd, unexpected, and creative ‚Äî the better.

üéØ Trains: sense of humor | creative thinking | spontaneous storytelling

task.en: You‚Äôll get an absurd word or phrase. Your task is to create a quirky, funny, but convincing advertisement as if you're selling it.

example.en:
Item: Hypnotic fork
Ad: Just one wave ‚Äî and soup jumps into your mouth! Convenient, silent, and comes with mild self-hypnosis!

description.en:
üåÄ In this exercise, you become a seller of nonsense ‚Äî you‚Äôll get a bizarre product name and create an ad so persuasive people might actually want it. Wacky, funny or brilliant ‚Äî as long as it sells!

üéØ Trains: creativity | sense of humor | persuasive skills

task.en: First, pronounce the tricky word slowly and clearly a few times. Focus on every sound ‚Äî no rushing, no swallowing. Then repeat it once or twice a bit faster, but keep the clarity.

example.en: Uncharacteristically ‚Äî un-cha-rac-te-ris-ti-cal-ly...

description.en:
üó£Ô∏è In this exercise, you‚Äôll train your pronunciation with a tricky word. First, say it slowly and clearly a few times ‚Äî break it into syllables and focus on every sound. Then repeat it a bit faster while keeping it sharp. The goal isn‚Äôt speed, but precision!

üéØ Trains: diction | articulation | speech tempo control

Strengthen your speech muscles ‚Äî and no word will be too tough!

task.en: Get a place and create a phrase that fits both that place and an intimate situation.

example.en:
Place: gym
Phrase: ‚ÄúYour moves make me lose control.‚Äù

description.en:
üòâ In this exercise, you‚Äôll get a random place ‚Äî and your task is to come up with a phrase that fits both that place and the bedroom. It‚Äôs a game of double meanings, where creativity, humor, and a touch of flirtation are your best tools.

üéØ Trains: creativity | wordplay | sense of humor

task.en: Get a random word and create a phrase with it that sounds like a flirt or a sexy hint.

example.en:
Word: deep
Phrase: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve gone so deep in my mind, I can‚Äôt think of anything else.‚Äù

description.en:
üòè One word ‚Äî and a whole universe of innuendos. In this exercise, you‚Äôll get a random word and try to craft a phrase that sounds like a playful hint or subtle flirt.

Time to test how well you can play with meanings and tone.

üéØ Trains: creativity | sensual intuition | flexible thinking

task.en: Get a random letter and create a sentence where all words start with that letter.

example.en:
Letter: S
Phrase: ‚ÄúSophie silently shaped secret stories.‚Äù

description.en:
üî§ In this exercise, a single letter becomes your whole world. You‚Äôll receive a random letter and must create a full sentence where every word starts with it.

üéØ Trains: vocabulary | linguistic flexibility | out-of-the-box thinking

task.en: See the word ‚Äî instantly say the first thing that comes to mind. Don‚Äôt overthink it!

example.en:
Word: Lightbulb ‚Üí Association: Light
Word: Sea ‚Üí Association: Water
Word: Book ‚Üí Association: Reading
Word: Coffee ‚Üí Association: Morning
Word: Airplane ‚Üí Association: Flight

description.en:
‚ö° Don‚Äôt think ‚Äî react! This exercise trains your mental speed: you see a word and instantly say the first association that comes to mind.

It‚Äôs a perfect way to boost your vocabulary and quick thinking.

üéØ Trains: speech speed | associative thinking | lexical agility

task.en: Get a letter and come up with at least 10 words that start with it

example.en:
Letter: C
Words: Cat, Cup, Car, Candle, Circle, Coin, Cookie, Clock, Cloud, Cave

description.en:
üí• One letter ‚Äî a vocabulary explosion! Get a letter and list at least ten words that start with it. Want a challenge? Try to come up with even more ‚Äî as fast as you can!

üéØ Trains: vocabulary | verbal speed | associative thinking

One letter ‚Äî endless possibilities. Keep going, don‚Äôt stop!

task.en: Get a topic and come up with at least 5 words that clearly match it.

example.en:
Category: Sports
Words: Football, Basketball, Running, Tennis, Swimming
Category: Emotions
Words: Joy, Anger, Sadness, Fear, Excitement

description.en:
üéØ This exercise gives you a topic ‚Äî your task is to quickly name five words that clearly relate to it. It‚Äôs a thinking challenge that boosts focus and activates your vocabulary.

üéØ Trains: thematic thinking | word selection | verbal speed

Five is the minimum. How many can you find without losing accuracy?

task.en: Get a profession and describe its worst possible representative.

example.en:
Profession: Hairdresser
Scenario: Uses a lighter and gasoline instead of scissors because it's 'faster and cheaper'.

description.en:
üò¨ In this exercise, you imagine the worst-ever representative of a profession ‚Äî like a hairdresser who burns hair instead of cutting it. Your task: get a profession and describe its ultimate anti-professional.

üéØ Trains: creativity | sense of humor

task.en: You‚Äôll get a funny or weird problem. Come up with the funniest or most unexpected solution.

example.en:
Problem: A saber-toothed tiger ate my wife while I was hunting.
Solution: Turn it into a pet so it stops eating people and guards the tribe instead.

Problem: At the wedding, the groom accidentally fell into the cake.
Solution: Declare it a new lucky tradition and make all the guests jump into it too.

description.en:
üß† In this exercise, you‚Äôll face a funny or weird problem. Your task: come up with an unexpected, creative, or totally absurd solution.

üéØ Trains: imagination | creativity | out-of-the-box thinking

task.en: You‚Äôll get a category and a letter. Come up with a word from that category starting with the given letter.

example.en:
Category: Animals
Letter: E
Answer: Elephant

Category: Fruits
Letter: M
Answer: Mango

description.en:
üî§ In this exercise, you‚Äôll get a random category and a letter. Your task: quickly think of a word that fits the category and starts with that letter ‚Äî like a fruit starting with ‚ÄúM‚Äù or an animal with ‚ÄúE‚Äù.

üéØ Trains: vocabulary | quick thinking | verbal agility

task.en: You‚Äôll get the first line of a dialogue ‚Äî your task is to continue the conversation. Come up with both your reply and the next line from the other person. Keep going for a few turns, making it sound natural and logical

example.en:
‚Äî Why didn‚Äôt you show up yesterday?
‚Äî Sorry, I had an emergency ‚Äî got stuck in an elevator!
‚Äî Seriously? For how long?
‚Äî Two hours. But the security guy brought me tea, so it wasn‚Äôt all bad.
‚Äî Alright then, forgiven. But next time ‚Äî at least text me!

description.en:
üó£Ô∏è In this exercise, you create a dialogue where you play both roles ‚Äî yourself and your imaginary conversation partner. You‚Äôll get the first line, then it‚Äôs your turn to improvise and keep the conversation going naturally and logically.

üéØ Trains: conversational flow | dialogue style | creativity

Think of it as a one-person show ‚Äî and have fun with it!

task.en: Say the sentence clearly and confidently. Every consonant should hit hard and punch through the mic ‚Äî no muffled sounds!

example.en: Zoe zipped zigzagging zippers on the zebra-striped jacket.

description.en:
üéôÔ∏è This exercise is all about clarity. You‚Äôll get a sentence packed with consonants and your goal is to pronounce each sound so clearly it punches through the mic. No smudging ‚Äî only crisp, confident articulation!

üéØ Trains: diction | speech clarity | vocal confidenc

task.en: Your task is to say a flirtatious, coquettish, or playful phrase addressing an inanimate object as if it were alive and could respond.

example.en: Example: ‚ÄúOh, my favorite coffee maker, you make my mornings perfect.‚Äù

description.en:
üíò In this exercise, you flirt with an inanimate object as if it were a living being. A flirty line for a toaster? A seductive phrase for a vacuum cleaner? Why not! Play with words, use your imagination, and make object-flirting unforgettable.

üéØ Trains: creativity | flirting | humor

Let yourself get romantic‚Ä¶ even with a lamp üòâ

task.en: You‚Äôll receive a neutral phrase and an emotion. Say the phrase with the right emotional coloring

example.en:
Phrase: ‚ÄúI'm going home‚Äù
Emotion: fear
Example: (voice trembling) I‚Ä¶ I'm going home‚Ä¶ (looks around, breathes anxiously)

description.en:
üé≠ In this exercise, you‚Äôll receive a neutral phrase and a specific emotion. Your task is to say the phrase so that the emotion is clearly felt in your voice. A simple phrase becomes your tool ‚Äî play with tone, pauses, pace, and imagined context. The key is to make the emotion sound sincere and convincing.

üéØ Trains: dramatic intonation | emotional sensitivity | vocal expressiveness

task.en: Start with one random word. For 60 seconds, build a chain: each new word must be logically or associatively linked to the previous one. The goal is to create the longest chain without stopping.

example.en: üîπ Word: water ‚Üí river ‚Üí boat ‚Üí paddle ‚Üí sport ‚Üí ball ‚Üí game‚Ä¶

description.en:
‚õì In this exercise, you train your ability to think fast and see connections between ideas. You start with one concept and create an associative chain ‚Äî word by word ‚Äî until time runs out.

üéØ Trains: quick thinking | verbal improvisation | communication flexibility

It‚Äôs not about precision ‚Äî it‚Äôs about flow. Let your brain jump freely from idea to idea!

task.en: You‚Äôll get a set of emojis. Create a short story where all of them are connected.

example.en: üåßÔ∏è‚òïüìñ ‚Üí 'Rain outside, coffee in hand, and a favorite book ‚Äî perfect morning.'

description.en:
üìö In this exercise, you‚Äôll get a set of emojis ‚Äî and your task is to come up with a short story where these emojis are logically or emotionally connected.

üéØ Trains: creativity | storytelling | emotional thinking
